utterances: Well, I'm torn with that too.
Yeah, it will.
It would make me sad and mostly because of my own - my own history with the Scouts is filled with great memories.
Qin Monson is a political scientist at Brigham Young University and a former Boy Scout.
Thanks so much for talking with us.
Thank you.
This is DAY TO DAY from NPR News.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
I'm Alex Cohen.
Today, a number of drug companies announced that they'll stop selling some over-the-counter cold and cough medicines for infants and toddlers.

Drug makers Johnson & Johnson, Novartis and Wyeth said they'll take a number of popular children's brands out of circulation this following report last month from the FDA, which linked overdoses of some of these drugs to the deaths of young children.
Joining me now to talk about today's news is DAY TO DAY's medical expert Dr. Sydney Spiesel.
He is a professor at the Yale Medical School and also, a practicing pediatrician.
Hi, Syd.
Hi, Alex.
Syd, which medications are we talking about?
Well, we're talking about all the medications that are marked for cauldron really from things like that.
Things like PediaCare, Triaminic and Tylenol drops that have additionally labeled for cold and cough and things like that.
There's nothing wrong with Tylenol, but it's the ingredient, which is used as a decongestant, which is now almost always for babies, it's phenylephrine.
We mentioned there was an FDA review of some of these medications.
What was the finding there?
What was the concern about these particular medications?
Well, there have been a bunch of deaths identified in the last three or four years.
There were 54 deaths identified in children under 2.
The thought was that these medications were over used and possibly inadvertently overused by parents.
You know, you want - you have a kid who feels bad.
You just want him to feel better.
And so people think that this stuff is safe and harmless.
And so, they've just been - they just keep giving doses and doses and doses.
So just to be clear here, usually on these packages, it will say: warning, do not exceed X amount of doses.
And so, we're talking about parents who may be run ahead and do that anyway?
I think that's probably true.
I think people often exceed the dosage listed on medication boxes.

There is a little bit of evidence that some people, for genetic reasons, which we - are only now beginning to detect, have a variation in the gene, which makes them exceptionally sensitive to the effects of phenylephrine.
But that is really not then part of this issue.
The real issue here is that people have been just overdosing their kids.
So Syd, you're a pediatrician.
You - should parents go to their medicine cabinet at home right now and throw out all of the children's cold remedies in the trash?
Well, first of all, this is directed at kids from up until 12 years old.
Those are the products that they're taking off the market.
Should they do that?
Well, maybe we should always done that partly because these things have little effect.
They have very little value.
Most of this stuff doesn't work.
So, let's say you're a parent out there right now.
And you've got a toddler, two years older younger who has a cough or runny nose, what advise can you give?
(Soundbite of laughter)
My advice, which people don't want to hear, is wipe the kid's nose.
That's opinion from Dr. Sydney Spiesel.
He's a pediatrician and a professor at the Yale Medical School.
You can read his medical examiner column at Slate.com.
Thanks again, Syd.
Thank you.
...And Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell this afternoon.
On Saturday, Iraq will hold its fourth parliamentary election since the toppling of Saddam Hussein.
Iraqis have paid a heavy price for the freedom to elect their leaders.
Now, though, many are so disillusioned with their previous governments that they say they won't vote this time around.
NPR's Jane Arraf reports from Baghdad.
UNIDENTIFIED PERSON #1: (Foreign language spoken).
To get to the Friday book market in Baghdad, you pass by streets filled with Iraqis selling their stuff on the sidewalk.
UNIDENTIFIED PERSON #2: (Foreign language spoken).
There are used clothes, kitchen odds and ends, worn plush toys each for less than 25 cents.
One of the vendors is Muwafaq Raheem, a former traffic cop.
He quit 10 years ago when police were being killed during Iraq's civil war.
He's been trying to get a job or a pension ever since.
He has no plans to vote.
(Through interpreter) I voted last time but never again - never.
They're the same faces, and what did we get from them?
There are a few reasons why this election could be genuinely different.
ISIS is mostly gone, and security has improved immensely.
Voters have a much bigger choice of candidates, and the country is generally less sectarian than it was during the worst of the violence here.
But past governments and a history of mismanagement and rampant corruption have left their mark.
(SOUNDBITE OF FLUTE MUSIC)
A few blocks away, al-Mutanabbi Street is the traditional beating heart of Baghdad cultural life.
(SOUNDBITE OF FLUTE MUSIC)
Young men sell wooden flutes.
Stacks of old and new books in English and Arabic spill out on the sidewalk.
(SOUNDBITE OF VIOLIN MUSIC)
In Qushla square just down the street, Iraqis crowd around wooden gazebos, listening to lectures on political thought or music and poetry.
(SOUNDBITE OF VIOLIN MUSIC)
This is where you normally find Iraqis who are politically engaged and young people believe their actions can make a difference.
But ahead of this election, they're hard to find.
Yassar Jabar is 29.
He's voted in the last three elections, but he doesn't plan to vote in this one.
He's upset because five years after graduating, he doesn't have a job.
(Through interpreter) Honestly, we've seen nothing good from the candidates I voted for.
So this time, I decided to vote for no one.
Shalan Zeidan has been selling books on the street for 20 years.
He's particularly distraught.
I ask him why he's not going to vote.
Why?
There is no result - no result.
We feel hopeless - no government, real government.
There is a tribe.
A tribe control us.
We have a tribe.
And we have gun.
Big fish eat small fish, and the big fish always win.
To be fair, a lot of Iraqis in past elections said they wouldn't vote, and then they changed their minds.
In elections four years ago, turnout was about 60 percent.
Millions of Iraqis will vote, but for many, their faith in democracy has been shaken.
Ranya Nashat is one of those.
She was a French horn player in Iraq's National Symphony Orchestra.
There is no orchestra now.
The Culture Ministry didn't renew contracts this year.
You can see, like, everything is so wrong.
That's why I'm not going to elect because it's the same faces every four year.
Neither my mom or my brother or my uncle or my other uncle or my aunt and friends - a lot of my friends are not going to elect this year.
(SOUNDBITE OF FLUTE MUSIC)
UNIDENTIFIED PERSON #3: (Foreign language spoken).
With the fall of Saddam in a country rich with oil, Iraqis expected a lot from their new democracy.
Young Iraqis in particular say they've been bitterly disappointed.
Jane Arraf, NPR News, Baghdad.
(SOUNDBITE OF MESSAGE TO BEARS' ""PRETEND TO FORGET"")
This WEEKEND EDITION from NPR News.
I'm Liane Hansen.
And joining us is puzzlemaster Will Shortz.
Hey, Will, happy new year.
